captions.text: You probably think of your bed as a cloud, or a cuddle zone, or a peaceful retreat from the world,
but here are 18 facts about your bed that might give you nightmares.
Over time mattresses gain wait as they absorb dead skin,
oil, saliva, sweat, blood, all kinds of other bodily fluids, and colonies of dust mites.
Maybe you've heard of dust mites, the little allergy inducing creatures that feed on our dead skin cells.
Every day we shed 1.5 grams of skin which is enough to feed 1 million dust mites. According to one study a made bead is more appealing to dust mites than a messy one,
but while an unmade bed might be better, dirty sheets are still bad. You should clean yours once a week.
A UK survey found that single men only wash their sheets four times a year, gross!
Dirty sheets can transfer contagious rashes, pink eye, and other unwelcome infections between slumber partiers.
Even if you're sleeping alone oily buildup that collects on your sheets can contribute to acne, so do yourself a favor and wash up.
One in five americans who have had or knows someone who has had a bed bug infestation probably told you that horror story.
But in case you missed it bedbugs are the worst. They can ingest seven times their own weight in blood.
That'd be like an average size male drinking a 120 gallons of liquid, except its your blood.
Bed bugs are hide and seek experts and like to hang out in tough to reach places so that they have easy access to human blood at night.
That coupled with the fact that they can withstand temperatures from nearly freezing to a 122 degrees Fahrenheit make them very, very hard to get rid of.
Snuggling up with your pup might be more dangerous than you think. Pets that sleep in bed with their owners can spread zoonoses. AKA pathogens that go from animals to people.
The risks are rare but the struggle is real. Protect yourself from your bed by vacuuming your mattress, investing in a mattress protecter, and cleaning your sheets weekly.

title: 18 Scary Facts About Where You Sleep
